qas.question: Why did the 2 districts have to be redrawn in 2014

answers.text: that at least two districts had to be redrawn because of gerrymandering

qas.question: How many were ruled to be redrawn in 2015

answers.text: lawmakers had followed an illegal and unconstitutional process overly influenced by party operatives, and ruled that at least eight districts had to be redrawn

qas.question: What was the court vote on the new congressional map in 2015

answers.text: a 5-2 majority of the Court accepted a new map of congressional districts

qas.question: Are there any more changes coming to the map

answers.text: There are likely to be additional challenges to the map and districts.

context: The court ruled in 2014, after lengthy testimony, <a0_0>that at least <b5_0>two districts had to be redrawn<b5_0/> because of <b4_0>gerrymandering<b4_0/><a0_0/>. After this was appealed, in July 2015 the Florida Supreme Court ruled that <a1_0>lawmakers had followed an illegal and unconstitutional process overly influenced by party operatives, and ruled that at least eight districts had to be redrawn<a1_0/>. On <b8_0>December 2, 2015<b8_0/>, <a2_0><b6_0>a <b7_0>5-2<b7_0/> majority of the Court accepted a new map of congressional districts<b6_0/><a2_0/>, some of which was drawn by challengers. Their ruling affirmed the map previously approved by Leon County Judge Terry Lewis, who had overseen the original trial. It particularly makes changes in South Florida. <a3_0>There are likely to be additional challenges to the map and districts.
